371enum EnumCameraLerpType
372{

374 CMLT_LINEAR = 1, ///< time is set to time / speed.
375 CMLT_LINEARLOOP = 2, ///< time is set to time / speed. If time is > 1.0 then time -= 1.0

458/**
459 * @class array<T>
460It is possible to declare array variables with the array identifier followed by the type of the elements within angle brackets.
461
462Example:
463
464 @code{.cpp}
465 array<int> a, b, c;
466 array<Foo@> d;
467 @endcode
468
469a, b, and c are now arrays of integers, and d is an array of handles to objects of the Foo type.
470
471When declaring arrays it is possible to define the initial size of the array by passing the length as a parameter to the constructor. The elements can also be individually initialized by specifying an initialization list. Example:
472
473 @code{.cpp}
474 array<int> a; // A zero-length array of integers
475 array<int> b(3); // An array of integers with 3 elements
476 array<int> c(3, 1); // An array of integers with 3 elements, all set to 1 by default
477 array<int> d = {5,6,7}; // An array of integers with 3 elements with specific values
478 @endcode
479
480Multidimensional arrays are supported as arrays of arrays, for example:
481
482 @code{.cpp}
483 array<array<int>> a; // An empty array of arrays of integers
484 array<array<int>> b = {{1,2},{3,4}} // A 2 by 2 array with initialized values
485 array<array<int>> c(10, array<int>(10)); // A 10 by 10 array of integers with uninitialized values
486 @endcode
487
488Each element in the array is accessed with the indexing operator. The indices are zero based, i.e. the range of valid indices are from 0 to length - 1.
489
490 @code{.cpp}
491 a[0] = some_value;
492 @endcode
493
494When the array stores handles the elements are assigned using the handle assignment.
495
496 @code{.cpp}
497 // Declare an array with initial length 1
498 array<Foo@> arr(1);
499 @endcode
500
501 @code{.cpp}
502 // Set the first element to point to a new instance of Foo
503 @arr[0] = Foo();
504 @endcode
505
506Arrays can also be created and initialized within expressions as anonymous objects.
507
508 @code{.cpp}
509 // Call a function that expects an array of integers as input
510 foo(array<int> = {1,2,3,4});
511 @endcode
512
513 */
514template <class T>
515class array<T>
516{
517public:
518 void insertAt(uint index, const T&in value); ///< Inserts a new element into the array at the specified index.
519 void insertAt(uint index, const T[]&inout arr); ///< Inserts another array of elements into the array at the specified index.
520 void insertLast(const T&in value); ///< Appends an element at the end of the array.
521 void removeAt(uint index); ///< Removes the element at the specified index.
522 void removeLast(); ///< Removes the last element of the array.
523 void removeRange(uint start, uint count); ///< Removes count elements starting from start.
524 uint length() const; ///< Returns the length of the array.
525 void reserve(uint length);
526 void resize(uint length); ///< Sets the new length of the array.
527 void sortAsc(); ///< Sorts the elements in the array in ascending order. For object types, this will use the type's opCmp method.
528 void sortAsc(uint startAt, uint count); ///< Sorts only the elements starting at index startAt and the following count elements in the array in ascending order. For object types, this will use the type's opCmp method.
529 void sortDesc(); ///< Sorts the elements in the array in descending order. For object types, this will use the type's opCmp method.
530 void sortDesc(uint startAt, uint count); ///< Sorts only the elements starting at index startAt and the following count elements in the array in descending order. For object types, this will use the type's opCmp method.
531 void reverse(); ///< Reverses the order of the elements in the array.
532
533 /**
534 * @brief Returns the index of the first element that has the same value as the wanted value.
535 * For object types, this will use the type's opEquals or opCmp method to compare the value. For arrays of handles any null handle will be skipped.
536 * If no match is found will return a negative value.
537 */
538 int find(const T&in value) const;
539
540 /**
541 * @brief Returns the index of the first element that has the same value as the wanted value.
542 * For object types, this will use the type's opEquals or opCmp method to compare the value. For arrays of handles any null handle will be skipped.
543 * If no match is found will return a negative value.
544 */
545 int find(uint startAt, const T&in value) const;
546
547 /**
548 * @brief Searches for a matching address. These are especially useful for arrays of handles where specific instances of objects are desired, and not just objects that happen to have equal value.
549 * If no match is found will return a negative value.
550 */
551 int findByRef(const T&in value) const;
552
553 /**
554 * @brief Searches for a matching address. These are especially useful for arrays of handles where specific instances of objects are desired, and not just objects that happen to have equal value.
555 * If no match is found will return a negative value.
556 */
557 int findByRef(uint startAt, const T&in value) const;
558 bool isEmpty() const;
559 T& opIndex(uint index);
560 const T& opIndex(uint index) const;
561 T[]& opAssign(const T[]&in);
562 bool opEquals(const T[]&in) const;
563 funcdef bool less(const ?&in a, const ?&in b); ///< sorting function for sort
564 void sort(less&in, uint startAt = 0, uint count = uint ( - 1 )); ///< sorts array using the passed in less function
565};

947 time = 0;

957 @endcode

965 * @param maxFrames

1379 /**
1380 * @brief Returns an area arg value
1381 * @param areaID
1382 * @param arg
1383 @code{.cpp}
1384
1385 though args can be used for anything, they are typically used in this fashion:
1386 0: warp ID
1387 1: warp level ID or trigger sound ID
1388 2: checkpoint ID
1389 3: tag ID
1390 4: floor damage hit points
1391 5: floor damage rate
1392
1393 Hardcoded:
1394 0: AAF_TELEPORT: WarpID
1395 1: AAF_TELEPORT: WarpLevelID, AAF_EVENT and AAF_EVENTSOUND: soundID to play when player enters sector
1396 2: AAF_CHECKPOINT or AAF_SAVEGAME: CheckpointID
1397 3: AAF_EVENT: tag ID
1398 4: Not used
1399 5: AAF_SECRET: the secret index value (set automatically when level loads starting at 0. Conflicts with AAF_DAMAGE (so I guess no secrets should be placed on damaga sectors))
1400
1401 Default Scripts:
1402 0: Not used
1403 1: Not used
1404 2: Not used
1405 3: Not used
1406 4: AAF_DAMAGE: amount of damage to do to the player when they're on the ground
1407 5: Always used as floor damage delay no matter the AAF flags. Should be used with AAF_DAMAGE only. 1 second = 1024
1408 @endcode
1409 */
1410 const int16 GetAreaArg(const int areaID, const int arg) const;
1411
1412 /**
1413 * @brief
1414 * @param areaID
1415 * @param arg
1416 @code{.cpp}
1417
1418 though args can be used for anything, they are typically used in this fashion:
1419 0: warp ID
1420 1: warp level ID or trigger sound ID
1421 2: checkpoint ID
1422 3: tag ID
1423 4: floor damage hit points
1424 5: floor damage rate
1425
1426 Hardcoded:
1427 0: AAF_TELEPORT: WarpID
1428 1: AAF_TELEPORT: WarpLevelID, AAF_EVENT and AAF_EVENTSOUND: soundID to play when player enters sector
1429 2: AAF_CHECKPOINT or AAF_SAVEGAME: CheckpointID
1430 3: AAF_EVENT: tag ID
1431 4: Not used
1432 5: AAF_SECRET: the secret index value (set automatically when level loads starting at 0. Conflicts with AAF_DAMAGE (so I guess no secrets should be placed on damaga sectors))
1433
1434 Default Scripts:
1435 0: Not used
1436 1: Not used
1437 2: Not used
1438 3: Not used
1439 4: AAF_DAMAGE: amount of damage to do to the player when they're on the ground
1440 5: Always used as floor damage delay no matter the AAF flags. Should be used with AAF_DAMAGE only. 1 second = 1024
1441 @endcode
1442 * @param value
1443 */
1444 void ChangeAreaArg(const int areaID, const int arg, const int16 value);
